dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, Donald Trump's steel tariffs under national security—was that a legitimate move or just protectionism in disguise?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Donald Trump's steel tariffs under national security-was that a legitimate move or just protectionism in disguise?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the text points out that many trading partners saw it as a fig leaf for protectionism, and they filed complaints with the WTO.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the text points out that many trading partners saw it as a fig leaf for protectionism, and they filed complaints with the W T O.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When former US President Donald Trump, citing national-security concerns, imposed tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, many of the United States trading partners viewed this as a fig leaf for protectionism and filed complaints with the WTO.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and then the US basically paralyzed the WTO's dispute-settlement body by not appointing new judges, so there was no way to resolve those conflicts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and then the U S basically paralyzed the W T O's dispute-settlement body by not appointing new judges, so there was no way to resolve those conflicts.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But Americas refusal to appoint new judges to the WTOs dispute-settlement body has left members without a functional mechanism to resolve such conflicts.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, which kind of undermines the whole system. But then you have these sanctions, like against Russia—they're supposed to be crippling, but are they actually working?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, which kind of undermines the whole system. But then you have these sanctions, like against Russia-they're supposed to be crippling, but are they actually working?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: The article says they've been largely unsuccessful. Like, Russian oil didn't stay below that $60 price cap; it went up to over $84 by December.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The article says they've been largely unsuccessful. Like, Russian oil didn't stay below that sixty dollars price cap; it went up to over eighty four dollars by December.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: These measures have been largely unsuccessful. By November 2023, it had risen to $84.20 as Russian companies developed various methods of circumventing Western restrictions, such as inflated shipping costs and a shadow fleet consisting of more than 100 old tankers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And they've got this whole shadow fleet of more than 100 old tankers to get around restrictions. It's like whack-a-mole with these evasion tactics.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they've got this whole shadow fleet of more than one hundred old tankers to get around restrictions. It's like whack-a-mole with these evasion tactics.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By November 2023, it had risen to $84.20 as Russian companies developed various methods of circumventing Western restrictions, such as inflated shipping costs and a shadow fleet consisting of more than 100 old tankers.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and then there's the ghost trade—over a billion dollars in sanctioned goods just vanishing. Countries like India and China are basically acting as intermediaries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and then there's the ghost trade-over a billion dollars in sanctioned goods just vanishing. Countries like India and China are basically acting as intermediaries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Meanwhile, more than $1 billion in sanctioned goods have reportedly vanished amid the expansion of the Russian ghost trade. Moreover, the Russia sanctions regime has given rise to a number of intermediaries, with countries like India, China, Armenia, Greece, Turkey, the United Arab Emirates, and Singapore effectively becoming laundromats for Russian oil and other sanctioned goods.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It reminds me of what happened with Iran's oil-smuggling network. Unless sanctions are nearly universal, they just don't stick.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It reminds me of what happened with Iran's oil-smuggling network. Unless sanctions are nearly universal, they just don't stick.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Iran, for example, has managed to circumvent Western sanctions by constructing a sophisticated oil-smuggling network. Unless they are nearly universal, however, trade sanctions are often less effective than expected.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the humanitarian costs are huge, too. The Cato Institute analysis from 2021 pointed out that US sanctions almost always fail to meet their goals.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the humanitarian costs are huge, too. The Cato Institute analysis from twenty twenty one pointed out that U S sanctions almost always fail to meet their goals.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As Richard Hanania observed in a 2020 Cato Institute analysis, US-imposed trade sanctions almost always fail to achieve their goals.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's financial sanctions—those seem to work better because of the dollar's dominance. Secondary sanctions during the Iraq War were way more effective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's financial sanctions-those seem to work better because of the dollar's dominance. Secondary sanctions during the Iraq War were way more effective.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: During the Iraq War, the US used financial sanctions to prevent American companies from dealing with counterparts in third-party countries that facilitated prohibited transactions with Iraq. These secondary sanctions proved to be significantly more effective than traditional commodity trade sanctions, largely owing to the dollars dominant role in global finance.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: True, but the more we use financial systems as weapons, the more other countries will look for alternatives to the dollar and SWIFT.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but the more we use financial systems as weapons, the more other countries will look for alternatives to the dollar and S W I F T.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But the longer the global financial system is used as a tool of economic warfare, the more governments and businesses in third-party countries will look for alternatives to the dollar, euro, and the SWIFT international payment system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which could really backfire on the US in the long run. If the dollar loses its prominence, the cost might far outweigh any short-term benefits.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which could really backfire on the U S in the long run. If the dollar loses its prominence, the cost might far outweigh any short-term benefits.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Should the Russia sanctions regime significantly erode the dollars prominence in international financial markets, the cost to the US and global economies could far exceed its benefits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So are we just stuck in this cycle where sanctions cause more problems than they solve?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So are we just stuck in this cycle where sanctions cause more problems than they solve?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It kinda seems that way, unless there's near-total global cooperation, which is almost impossible to achieve.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It kinda seems that way, unless there's near-total global cooperation, which is almost impossible to achieve.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Goods sanctions are most effective when they are imposed by virtually the entire world. Unless they are nearly universal, however, trade sanctions are often less effective than expected.

artist_script:
HostA: So, Donald Trump's steel tariffs under national security—was that a legitimate move or just protectionism in disguise?
HostB: Well, the text points out that many trading partners saw it as a fig leaf for protectionism, and they filed complaints with the WTO.
HostA: Right, and then the US basically paralyzed the WTO's dispute-settlement body by not appointing new judges, so there was no way to resolve those conflicts.
HostB: Exactly, which kind of undermines the whole system. But then you have these sanctions, like against Russia—they’re supposed to be crippling, but are they actually working?
HostA: The article says they’ve been largely unsuccessful. Like, Russian oil didn’t stay below that $60 price cap; it went up to over $84 by December.
HostB: And they’ve got this whole shadow fleet of more than 100 old tankers to get around restrictions. It’s like whack-a-mole with these evasion tactics.
HostA: Yeah, and then there’s the ghost trade—over a billion dollars in sanctioned goods just vanishing. Countries like India and China are basically acting as intermediaries.
HostB: It reminds me of what happened with Iran’s oil-smuggling network. Unless sanctions are nearly universal, they just don’t stick.
HostA: And the humanitarian costs are huge, too. The Cato Institute analysis from 2021 pointed out that US sanctions almost always fail to meet their goals.
HostB: But then there’s financial sanctions—those seem to work better because of the dollar’s dominance. Secondary sanctions during the Iraq War were way more effective.
HostA: True, but the more we use financial systems as weapons, the more other countries will look for alternatives to the dollar and SWIFT.
HostB: Which could really backfire on the US in the long run. If the dollar loses its prominence, the cost might far outweigh any short-term benefits.
HostA: So are we just stuck in this cycle where sanctions cause more problems than they solve?
HostB: It kinda seems that way, unless there’s near-total global cooperation, which is almost impossible to achieve.
